abstract: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.
snippet: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street ended slightly higher on Tuesday as an energized technology sector helped offset worries about foreign debt.

headline.main: Wall Street Manages to Stay on Positive Side

abstract: Bank of America and Merrill Lynch were accused of discriminating against women in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by three female financial advisers at the companies, The Associated Press reported.
snippet: Bank of America and Merrill Lynch were accused of discriminating against women in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by three female financial advisers at the companies, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America and Merrill Lynch were accused of discriminating against women in a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by three female financial advisers at the companies, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: 3 Women Sue BofA and Merrill Lynch Over Bias

abstract: Madison Dearborn is coughing up almost $485 million in cash to buy out BWAY Holding, a maker of plastic and steel containers, The Associated Press reported.
snippet: Madison Dearborn is coughing up almost $485 million in cash to buy out BWAY Holding, a maker of plastic and steel containers, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: Madison Dearborn Partners is paying almost $485 million in cash to buy out Bway Holding, a maker of plastic and steel containers, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: Madison Dearborn Signs Deal for BWAY

abstract: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission said Wednesday that it would question Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman; Charles O. Prince, Citigroup’s former chief executive, and Robert E. Rubin, a Citi director, during three days of hearings next week.
snippet: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission said Wednesday that it would question Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman; Charles O. Prince, Citigroup’s former chief executive, and Robert E. Rubin, a Citi director, during three days of he...
lead_paragraph: Get ready for Round Two in the search for answers about why the financial system nearly collapsed in 2008.

headline.main: Crisis Panel Hot Seat Awaits Rubin and Prince
